extracted_information: The `prefers-reduced-motion` CSS media feature detects if a user has enabled a device setting to minimize non-essential motion, allowing browsers to render interfaces with reduced, removed, or replaced motion-based animations. This is crucial for accessibility, especially for individuals with vestibular motion disorders, as animations like scaling or panning can be triggers.

values.no-preference: Indicates no user preference is known. Evaluates as false.
values.reduce: Indicates user has enabled reduced motion setting. Evaluates as true. `@media (prefers-reduced-motion)` is equivalent to `@media (prefers-reduced-motion: reduce)`.

features: Detects user's device setting for minimizing non-essential motion.
Allows developers to adapt UI animations (remove, reduce, replace) based on user preference.
Enhances accessibility for users with vestibular motion disorders by preventing motion-induced discomfort.

implementation_examples.description: An example demonstrates switching a scaling animation to a more muted 'dissolve' animation when the `prefers-reduced-motion` media query detects the user's preference for reduced motion. This is achieved by defining alternative CSS rules with the same specificity but appearing later in the CSS source order, taking precedence when the condition is met.

browser_support: Widely available across many devices and browser versions since January 2020.

Firefox: In GTK/GNOME: Settings > Accessibility > Seeing > Reduced animation (turned on).
In older GNOME: GNOME Tweaks > General tab (or Appearance) > Animations (turned off).
Alternatively: Add `gtk-enable-animations = false` to the `[Settings]` block of the GTK 3 configuration file.
In Plasma/KDE: System Settings > Workspace Behavior -> General Behavior > 'Animation speed' (set to 'Instant').
In `about:config`: Add number preference `ui.prefersReducedMotion` and set value to `1` for reduced motion (or `0` for full animation). Changes take effect immediately.

Windows.Windows_10: Settings > Ease of Access > Display > Show animations in Windows.
Windows.Windows_11: Settings > Accessibility > Visual Effects > Animation Effects.

user_settings_configuration.macOS: System Preferences > Accessibility > Display > Reduce motion.

best_practices: Always respect the `prefers-reduced-motion` setting to improve accessibility for users with motion sensitivities.
Provide alternative, less motion-intensive animations (e.g., fades, dissolves) instead of aggressive scaling, panning, or parallax effects.
Warn users about potentially problematic animations on pages, especially if a full motion experience is crucial for understanding content.
